gov.usgs.locator

Class LinearStep

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.usgs.locator.LinearStep

  • public class LinearStep
extends java.lang.Object
    Computing seismic travel times is expensive, so instead set the steepest descent step length using the linear term of a Taylor series. The residual estimates and hence the estimated penalty function value will be accurate as long as the curvature of the Earth is negligible within the step length (and, of course, the seismic phases still exist at the new epicentral distance and hypocentral depth).
    Author:
    Ray Buland

    • Method Detail

      • stepLength

        public RestResult stepLength(double[] stepDir,
                             double startLen,
                             double stepMin,
                             double stepMax,
                             double curPenalty)
                      throws java.lang.Exception
        Determine the step length in the steepest descents step direction that results in the minimum dispersion based on linear estimates of the travel-time residuals. This algorithm is a messy bisection.
        Parameters:
        stepDir - Spatial steepest descents direction unit vector
        startLen - Starting step length in kilometers
        stepMin - If the step length is less than the minimum the current estimate is good enough
        stepMax - If the final step length is greater than the maximum, give up
        curPenalty - Current R-estimator dispersion
        Returns:
        The step length in kilometers needed to reach the minimum dispersion
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - If the bisection doesn't make sense

      • getTrialVector

        public double[] getTrialVector()
        Get the final trial vector. The current hypocenter will be moved by this much for this iteration.
        Returns:
        Trial spatial vector in kilometers
